citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An 8 year old male chihuahua named “Elvis” contained a mobile front incisor and moderate diffuse dental calculi. The
condition had not been observed by the licensee and had not been communicated to the AV. Daily observations of all
animals are important to assess their health and well-being, so problems can be communicated to the AV or treated as
directed in the Veterinary care plan. Correct from this day forward by ensuring daily observations are done in a thorough
manner to ensure that all problems are addressed quickly.

3 adult dogs over 4 months of age have not been added to the facility’s Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on Hand
(APHIS form 7005). Accurate acquisition information is necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of
animals during inspection and to properly trace their movements. The licensee shall make, keep, and maintain an
approved method of documentation which fully and correctly discloses all information concerning each dog purchased or
otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported,
euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while
in his or her possession or under his or her control. The licensee must record the acquisition information on an approved
document for all dogs and ensure all required acquisition information is properly and accurately documented at all times.
To be corrected by: 13-November-2023

A five and a half month old chihuahua named Mason has not received a rabies vaccine. Per the program of veterinary
care, the dog is to receive a Rabies vaccine at 16 weeks of age. Not vaccinating all adults dogs for rabies doesn't ensure
the dogs are adequately protected. All adult dogs must be vaccinated for rabies in accordance with the plan from the
Attending Veterinarian.
To be corrected by: 13-November-2023

Medical records were not complete for 12 dogs at the facility after completion of annual exams on 8/5/2023. While the
facility maintained receipts showing the veterinary visit and diagnostics/preventatives performed, there were no medical
records documenting the date the problem occurred, or examination findings to describe the extent of the injury, test
results, and next steps moving forward for treatment and care. Incomplete records do not allow the identification of
medical problems as they arise, does not ensure adequate care is provided, and does not allow close monitoring of
conditions as they progress. Dealers must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make them available during
inspection.
To be corrected by: 20-November-2023
This inspection and exit interview was conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
KEVIN WILKEN, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An 8 year old male chihuahua named “Elvis” contained a mobile front incisor and moderate diffuse dental calculi. The 
condition had not been observed by the licensee and had not been communicated to the AV. Daily observations of all 
animals are important to assess their health and well-being, so problems can be communicated to the AV or treated as 
directed in the Veterinary care plan. Correct from this day forward by ensuring daily observations are done in a thorough 
manner to ensure that all problems are addressed quickly. 
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
3 adult dogs over 4 months of age have not been added to the facility’s Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on Hand 
(APHIS form 7005). Accurate acquisition information is necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of 
animals during inspection and to properly trace their movements. The licensee shall make, keep, and maintain an 
approved method of documentation which fully and correctly discloses all information concerning each dog purchased or 
otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, 
euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while 
in his or her possession or under his or her control. The licensee must record the acquisition information on an approved 
document for all dogs and ensure all required acquisition information is properly and accurately documented at all times. 
To be corrected by: 13-November-2023 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
A five and a half month old chihuahua named Mason has not received a rabies vaccine. Per the program of veterinary 
care, the dog is to receive a Rabies vaccine at 16 weeks of age. Not vaccinating all adults dogs for rabies doesn't ensure 
the dogs are adequately protected. All adult dogs must be vaccinated for rabies in accordance with the plan from the 
Attending Veterinarian. 
To be corrected by: 13-November-2023 
3.13(b)

Veterinary care for dogs. 
Medical records were not complete for 12 dogs at the facility after completion of annual exams on 8/5/2023. While the 
facility maintained receipts showing the veterinary visit and diagnostics/preventatives performed, there were no medical 
records documenting the date the problem occurred, or examination findings to describe the extent of the injury, test 
results, and next steps moving forward for treatment and care. Incomplete records do not allow the identification of 
medical problems as they arise, does not ensure adequate care is provided, and does not allow close monitoring of 
conditions as they progress. Dealers must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make them available during 
inspection.  
To be corrected by: 20-November-2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview was conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KEVIN WILKEN, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
